For the discerning bandit or the sensitive Doman, this scarf can be used to filter unpleasant odors.
Either Shamani Lohmani's wine is gaining recognition, or F'lhaminn has a soft spot for the blind vintner.

Not fit for consumption, but ideal for baiting cobras.

A timeworn map revealing the location of a buried alexandrite cache.

Foodstuffs pilfered from the stores in Costa del Sol.

Sewn in a competent fashion by a reasonably talented tailor using materials of a satisfactory quality, these garments have been kept in acceptable shape and more than likely commanded an average-to-fair price at market.
An expertly tailored dress certain to make eyes bulge and hearts stop.
Within its brittle pages are detailed sketchings of landscapes and vistas numbering in the hundreds.
A complex lock prevents any and all from uncovering the secret of the legendary pirate king Mistbeard's treasure.
A simple leather satchel belonging to an adventurer no longer adventuring in the corporeal realm.

Designed for shearing the wool from sheep, it is not recommended that one use the blade to remove whiskers from a feral croc, as it will more than likely damage the knife permanently.

The faint pulse of ancient magicks can be felt within this polished blue gem.
The faint pulse of ancient magicks can be felt within this polished yellow gem.
Over-aspected aether manifested into solid form.
A handwritten missive from ARuhnSenna to his sister RayaOSenna.
Part of a not-so-elaborate plan to draw forth the postmaster moogle from his postmaster spot of hiding.
A letter addressed to Storm Sergeant Swygrael of the Red Swallows unit stationed in Camp Overlook.
A missive addressed to Guildmaster Wawalago from Ul'dahn merchant Rorojaru.
Upon this folded slip of parchment is written the location of Wawalago's planned fish exchange.
A letter to the aesthetician Jandelaine, written in an elegant hand whose loops and flourishes exude naught but sophistication.
The words “Property of Rorojaru! Open under penalty of DEATH!” have been scrawled multiple times on each of the crate's six sides.
A small iron key found in the caverns of Snowcloak. It is far colder to the touch than one would expect.
A grotesque key crafted from what appears to be the bones of an Elezen...
Markedly heavy for an envelope and some parchment.
A letter penned by Mauh Lihzeh to her long-lost sister.
The relic daggers Yoshimitsu, in such poor repair as to render them unfit for use.

A fine-grain form of the mineral alumina found in the stomach of the dhorme chimera. It is believed the creature grinds chunks of alumina ore with its powerful jaws and swallows the resulting powder to use as a catalyst for its fiery breath.
A carved stone tablet dating back to the Fifth Astral Era. Sought by naturalists and collectors of relics.
A tome containing details on the life of the legendary ninja Sasuke.
This glowing chunk of the Lord of the Inferno's corporeal flesh burns without being consumed.
When released, the Lady of the Vortex's wail has the sheer force to shatter solid rock.
Precious ore melted and fused with molten volcanic rock heated by the rage of the Lord of Crags.
A rough estimate puts the number of letters addressed to gladiator Franz the Fair in this tightly bound bundle at approximately five score.
A notice informing the paying public of an upcoming gladiatorial match featuring one Franz the Fair...and some other fighter whose name is not important.

A notice informing the paying public of an upcoming gladiatorial match featuring one Franz the Fair. The number of exclamation points used on the leaflet suggests the printer may have charged by the character.
An old glass bottle filled with what appears to be wine...but you cannot be certain.
An antiquated grimoire stolen from Rowena's House of Splendors.
Without a ring from this shiny metal bell, your Bonding Ceremony guests will be required to wait what will surely feel like an eternity before moving to the next step in the proceedings.
A thick envelope addressed to simply “the Homunculi”─a popular band of traveling bards infamous for siring bastards in all the towns they tour.
A long list of items purchased from adventurers by Black Rabbit Traders.
A slip of parchment documenting commercial dealings with the Baert Trading Company of Ul'dah.
A copy of the exclusive employment contract drawn up by Rishushu and signed by the Homunculi.
A copy of the investigative report conducted by Rishushu documenting trade in Gridania.
Discovered on the body of a slain heretic, this yellowing document is covered in a complex code of seemingly random letters and numbers.
The blackish-green stain of humours spilled from a wounded gut cover a large portion of this letter.
A small iron key that may be of foreign design, for it does not match the style found in other artifacts seen in the Wanderer's Palace.
An arduous pilgrimage to each of Eorzea's monuments to the Twelve has seen this divine ring further blessed.
When applied to an ear, this beautifully crafted accessory is certain to draw attention from the other side of your head.
A letter penned by Urha Lihzeh to her sister.
The deputy postmoogle assures you this missive is intended for delivery to Wymond despite the lack of legible markings on the envelope.
A lengthy list instructing Raymond what the Purple Haze require if he is to see his daughter again...in one piece.
A promissory note documenting the considerable amount of gil borrowed in Wymond's name from one of the realm's most prestigious banks.
A futures contract for ceruleum with Syntgoht.
A gift from Raymond's wife to an old friend.
A letter addressed to Professor Lamberteint from one of his self-professed “greatest pupils.”
A four-volume compilation of Professor Lamberteint's theories on the process of manually altering an object's elemental aspect.
These marvels of nature are certain to be the highlight of Professor Lamberteint's symposium.
A simple clay pot that has been treated on the inside with a special alchemical sealant to prevent aetherial conductivity.
This miner's tool has been outfitted with a special head designed to allow its user better control when attempting to coerce corrupted crystals from their rocky beds.
A warded pot filled to the brim with corrupted crystals.
A mysterious communication addressed to the hermit Drest supposedly residing at the Severed String.
Inside rests Drest's fortune, though it is considerably lighter than you would expect from a “hoard.”
A scroll full of testimonies written in Blaisie's meticulous hand, outlining any dubious activities shopkeeps and citizens of the Jeweled Crozier have recently witnessed.
A flimsy slip of paper with hastily penned accusations written upon it, alleging that Archombadin de Dzemael is responsible for Ulaa's kidnapping.
The infamous tome of parables on equality said to have mysteriously vanished off the library shelves shortly prior to Ulaa's equally inexplicable disappearance.
A creepy lantern carved from a pumpkin, typically seen during All Saints' Wake.
A wooden box filled with contraband.
A personal message addressed to the leader of the White Rams.
An urgent message written by Hihibaru to his only daughter.
The thick taproot of the Trader vetch─a hardy shrub that commonly grows in deserts and other arid landscapes.
A simple band of silver links worn by Hihira's mother before she passed.
A not-so-gentlemanly behest for a not-so-jolly bout of mortal combat from one addle-pated pirate, Fiebras, to another, Anselm.
An official request to one Cocobuki for assistance in an investigation being held by the Ul'dah city guard.
A register cataloging all the tomes kept in the guild library.
A letter addressed to the Qiqirn entrepreneur from Brugaire Consortium vice-chairman, Bango Zango.
Developed in the 43rd year of the first Garlean emperor's reign, this trigger device works with all imperial Mark XLIII anti-aircraft cannons.
A large wooden box containing all sorts of detritus gathered from the Coliseum, some of it still twitching...
Battlefields the day after slaughter smell better than the unknown contents of this bag.
A leather bag containing what feels to be a substantial amount of gil.
A barely legible notice announcing the Continental Circus's forthcoming parade.

A plain wrapped box, unmarked save for the words, “Dutiful Sisters of the Edelweiss.”
A secret blend of eleven herbs and grasses that is certain to win over any wary wooly.
The Brass Blade captain's wife obviously took impeccable care of these spectacles...until she forgot them, that is.
As long as an arm, as straight as an arrow, and oh, so yellow.
Written by a child of Eorzea, this quaint message details the material wishes of an innocent soul.
This gift was made possible by the donations of an anonymous philanthropist.

A wicked outgrowth torn from the skull of the dread voidsent Batraal. Sought by naturalists and collectors of relics.
The protective armor plating of a gobmachine G-VI. Sought by naturalists and collectors of relics.
The iron-like skin of the terrible Narasimha. Sought by naturalists and collectors of relics.
The crescent-shaped canine of the legendary spirit-hound Fenrir. Sought by naturalists and collectors of relics.
A cankerous ore found only in the Aurum Vale.
One can only imagine the manner of cursed loom which joined the warp and weft of this corrupt cloth.
If truly a relic from the age of Amdapor, then the white magicks preventing this page from crumbling to dust are far more powerful than the spells which remain today.
Almost pure white in color, the Indigo pearl earns its name from the sea in which they are found.
Though long removed from its owner, the scarlet humours still boil hot with rancor.
And with this vial ends the bloodline of the hecatoncheir king Ouranos...until a new king is spawned.

It is believed that the curse which animates the unliving rock within the Sunken Temple of Qarn originates from the blood of the Warden's vicegerent.
A treasure once lost...and now found.
A treasure once lost...and now found.
A treasure once lost...and now found.
A treasure once lost...and now found.
A collection of little-known postmoogle trivia compiled in a concise ten-page portfolio.
This tiny glass container appears to have been used before...but to contain what, pray tell?
A sack of gil received from Yda in exchange for a single moon daisy.
Moon daisies are often hung to rafters, trees, or other elevated locations to represent the celestial body when performing holy rituals to the goddess Menphina during daylight hours.
Suspected to supposedly contain something like explosives.
Great power can be felt coursing through this pipe of Far Eastern design.
Whether deliberately or not, the sender of this missive failed to mark the envelope with a return address.
A faded map detailing the location of treasure buried during the rule of House Thorne.
Using powerful oneiromancy, the archmagus Noah sealed within this spherical gem lost memories of the Labyrinth of the Ancients.
Using powerful oneiromancy, the archmagus Noah sealed within this spherical gem lost memories of Syrcus Tower.
Using powerful oneiromancy, the archmagus Noah sealed within this spherical gem lost memories of the World of Darkness.
Allows the bearer passage on Highwind Skyway's private charter flights to and from the Manderville Gold Saucer.
A sweet-smelling gift exchanged by lovers on Valentione's Day. Its pleasant aroma comes from the rare Gridanian wood from which it is carved.
A single raw topaz accompanies the love letter contained inside this simple envelope.
A popular gift on Valentione's Day, fragrant oil extracted from the spearmint plant was added to this chocolate during the crafting process.
Tattered cloth taken from the raiment of a powerful wraith.
A second pass through an alembic has removed nearly all of the impurities once contained in this water.

Distilled in Jalzahn's private cellarage using a recipe handed down through his family for sixteen generations (give or take a few generations), these mind-clearing, belly-warming, lacquer-removing spirits are as sweet on the lips as the sun's kiss.
A Hatching-tide prize voucher redeemable at any Hatching-tide helpmeet.
A premium Hatching-tide prize voucher redeemable at any Hatching-tide helpmeet.
Crafted from butterfly scales and imbued with magic, this projectile will envelop its target in a thick blanket of (mostly harmless) smoke.

Crafted from butterfly scales and imbued with magic, this projectile will reveal the true form of that which it strikes. Though it serves the exact same purpose as a trueform scalebomb, for some reason, it does not share its name.
An alchemical creation that serves to dispel glamours.
A thin, rectangular piece of what appears to be cermet. Used to deactivate certain magitek security terminals.
These oval rocks are believed to be the “seeds” from which the floating islets of the Sea of Clouds and the Churning Mists are born.
An ordinary steel lever useful for repairing items such as damaged minecart brakes, trap doors, and gate winches.
A rusty iron key used to open the door to the Dusk Vigil barracks.
A burnished brass key used to open the door to the lord commander's seat in the Dusk Vigil.
Thick, deep-grey bristles sheared from a wild beast.
A once-hot package unintentionally left by Ysaudore to cool in the frigid highland winds.
A crystal so aspected to water that it feels wet to the touch.
Research compiled by Matoya on a device known as an aetheric converger.
What appears to be a record of past correspondence held between individuals regarded as heretics by the Holy See.
The tender tail meat of an underdeveloped ninki nanka.
The tender tail meat of an underdeveloped ninki nanka.
Lack of imagination has led to most white flowers found growing in the skybound regions of Dravania and Abalathia to be named after clouds, this light-petaled specimen being no exception.

An ordinary rock awash with extraordinary color. What that color represents, however, you cannot discern from any angle.
The bristly hide of a (now hideless) yak.
One of three keystones used to seal the Wanderer's Palace.
One of three keystones used to seal the Wanderer's Palace.
As empty as the day it was made.
Items believed to be carried on the person of a void scholar gone missing five summers past.
An aged battleaxe, featureless but for the initials MH crudely engraved into the haft.
A lifeless salmon, the last of its energy spent spawning in the upper Whilom River.
This nameless flora has a pleasant enough scent to suggest it is most likely not poisonous.
This wine is cooled after its first mulling and allowed to sit for a fortnight before mulling a second time with a fresh muslin bag of spices. For delivery to one Hierytha.
This wine is cooled after its first mulling and allowed to sit for a fortnight before mulling a second time with a fresh muslin bag of spices. For delivery to one Gerraldieux.
When dried and smoked, lean steinbock meat will remain unspoiled in the cold Coerthan air almost indefinitely.
Items used by Ingaret's grandfather when he was a ferryman on the Swiftrun River.
One of three pieces of a talisman carried by an Ishgardian knight for good luck.
The lean sinewy meat of a fully grown gastornis.
War rations freshly prepared by the Rose Knight cook serving at Camp Cloudtop.
The leathery membrane of this gaelicat wing is in pristine condition. A perfect specimen for study.
It has been requested that you place these flowers on the grave of a long-lost loved one.
Various barbuts, bevors, and bracers stolen from the Rosehouse by the Vanu Vanu.
Soft yak wool perfect for protecting one from the bitter winds of Coerthas.
An empty wine bottle that Jantellot has asked you to refill not with wine, but with water from the hot springs known as Dragonspit.
Water from the hot springs at Dragonspit is believed to harbor healing powers, beneficial when both applied externally, or taken internally.
A yellow feather fallen from an Ishgardian battle chocobo. How can one tell the difference between a battle chocobo feather and any other chocobo feather? Practice.
Quite sizable for a kitten, something tells you that this may not be your ordinary pet.
At night, the long, narrow caps of these mushrooms emit a faint glow, giving the lampshades their name.
So covered are these gysahl greens in white lampshade spores that they have no purpose being called “greens” anymore.
A yellowish brown liquid with the consistency of mud and an odor that would cause a zombie's nose to wrinkle.
This bow is small and light, and while it may not have the power or range of a longbow, it is suitable for hunting in forests or similarly tight-quartered areas.
Scores of tiny black eggs suspended in a sac of foul-smelling slime. Adult nankas carry these sacs on their backs until incubation is complete.
Though slightly bruised from its long fall, this caelumtree fruit appears ready to eat.
Meat so fresh you can still hear the death throes of the beast you sliced it from.
A queerly shaped firearm wielded by the beast tribe's firedrones.
This clay, only found in the Dravanian foothills of Abalathia's Spine, turns a deep ocher when fired in a kiln─a color unachievable with any other Eorzean clay.
A fragrant herb with silver leaves that, when rubbed, turn a bright green.
An unidentifiable yellow substance covers this otherwise ordinary stone.
A lumpy bag retrieved from a Vathic wain.
Enough firesand to tear a hole in an ilm-thick steel plate. Take care when dancing around bonfires.
Despite being the toughest meat on a miacid, the tail is possibly the most palatable.
The countless bumps and barbs which cover this eggshell almost make you feel sorry for the gallimimus who laid it.
If not for its size, this slice of pink meat would appear no different than a common rooster's thigh.
Marinated in sweet buttermilk, lightly dusted in a mixture of millioncorn and sunset wheat flours, then deep-fried in oil to a golden brown. You know you want a taste.
The coarse yet supple hide of a hippocerf.
A plain grey flint stone entrusted to you by the Vath fleetfoot.
A Dravanian forelands flower whose dragonspeak name roughly translates into “summer tree.”
The magicks imbued within this scale torn from the back of Kohm Khur are so great, you can feel them pulse in your hand.
The thick fibrous vine of a sankchinni. New roots have already begun to shoot forth from the exposed cut.
This beautiful flower blooms only once every spring. The rest of the year, the plant is considered one of the ugliest in all the land.
Sealed with a lid woven from the same grass as the body, this basket contains several small items indiscernible through the myriad holes in the weave.
While the high concentration of beastkin dung contained in this textured soil makes it suited for growing all manner of plants, it also makes it reek to the seventh heaven.
The flavorful seed of a kupo tree, the kupo nut is cherished by moogles across the realm. This particular nut is especially plump.
Worn down by centuries of exposure to the elements, the purpose of this man-made tool remains a mystery.
Normally attached to the bottom rim of a breastplate to protect its wearer from deadly thrusts to the buttocks, this culet appears to have become detached from Ser Heustienne's suit of mail.
This small piece of vellum covered in arcane markings appears to be cut from a larger piece─possibly a page from a stolen tome.

Moogles believe that chewing the moca leaf lifts spirits, making it easier to accomplish more work. This does not seem to be the case with non-moogles, the leaf having no noticeable effects outside of turning one's mouth green.
An undecorated clay ewer containing nothing but the memory of cool spring water.
An undecorated clay ewer filled to the brim with cool spring water.
An ornate blade crafted by Moghome chieftain, Moglin.
These Mists biast scales are covered in a thin layer of viscous liquid numbing to the touch.
A metal fragment broken off an item most likely left by the landlords who inhabited the Churning Mists over a millennium past.
Even with only a single pair of leaves having sprouted from the soil, this seedling already is producing the snap, crackle, and popping noises associated with the flora.
A strangely heavy basket woven with one of the thick grasses native to the islets floating atop the Churning Mists.
The gnarled appendage of a living tree once occupied by a melia.
This Mists drake tail is the best you ever had.
The magick-imbued heart of a limestone golem.
Only two tiny sets of leaves have yet to form on this seedling that, when fully grown, will still only measure two or three ilms tall.
Despite being lighter than air, this floating flora will not budge from its location even when beset by strong winds.
An old tool left by the landlords─its purpose lost to the winds of time.
A metallic ring that, while obviously very old, has somehow maintained its luster.
Almost entirely covered in ice crystals, this zoblyn carapace remains cold to the touch, long after being removed from its former owner.
Blood red meat deftly sliced from the massive upper leg of a wisent.
Soft, warm, and smelling of rich earth, anything planted in this soil is certain to thrive.
The shell of this phurble-sized egg is so hard that a sledgehammer is required to crack it.
An odd contraption used for measuring surrounding aether levels. This particular device has been specially tuned in order to optimize performance in regions of thinner air.
A report detailing an Ishgardian scout's survey of the surrounding area.
An odd contraption used for measuring surrounding aether levels. This particular device has been specially tuned in order to optimize performance in regions of thinner air.
This crate containing aetherometers has been branded with the seal of the Knights Dragoon.
The result of several moons of monitoring dragon activity in and nearby the Aery.
For centuries, farmers on the northern fringes of the Black Shroud, as well as the Coerthas lowlands, have planted this hardy flower in early spring as a cover crop to increase soil fertility.

Grown under the strict supervision of the Greatloam Growery's finest botanists, the leaves on this particular bunch of greens are almost twice the size of those seen in local markets and fodder shops.
A report written by herbalist Martineau detailing the differences between two varieties of edible flora.
While the penmanship used on the envelope is impeccable, the lettering is so tiny that a loupe is required to make out that the letter is to be delivered to Roiteloin.
The tough skin has been removed from this wamoura larva, leaving naught but a writhing mass of sticky flesh ready to pop into your mouth.
The carefully sharpened claw of a violent endymion.
One of many carnivorous plants found growing on the Sea of Clouds' floating islets. Fortunately for you, this one seems content with dining on vilekin.
Tribute paid by the Zundu tribe to the Vundu tribe.
Several notches have been expertly carved into the base of this quill which serves as a key to a Zundu manacle lock.
A sour-smelling liquid that is supposed to cure paralysis.
If not for its size, this slice of pink meat would appear no different than a common rooster's thigh. You wonder if it might have a similar flavor...
A mimsy slice of slippery meat snicker-snacked from a galumphing bandersnatch's rump.

Before thinking that Carvallain will never miss a few coins from this already-hefty haul, recall the last time the ex-pirate-turned-importer discovered a payment a tad too light, and replaced the missing weight with the tips of the carrier's fingers.
A ridiculously expensive vintage handcrafted by realm-renowned winemaker Shamani Lohmani of Wineport.
A large kupo nut dropped by the unmaneuvering moogle.
An abundance of molted down in this empty nest suggests that its former inhabitants grew large enough to set out on their own.
The egg of one of Nidhogg's direct descendants. It is still slightly warm to the touch.
The top half of this battle-worn weapon's aichme has been snapped clean off. The shaft and sauroter, however, appear to be in serviceable condition.
A battle-worn spearhead. The furite used in its creation gives the blade a deep-red glow.
A massive nest constructed of not only twigs, but of salvaged arrows, strips of hemp and leather, even bones...
A circular plate affixed below the armpit to deflect sword or lance thrusts. This one is rusted clean through.
Weapons and armor of fallen knights.
A passionate entreaty for aid penned by the Padjal Raya-O-Senna.
A by-product of Alaqa's dark experiments.
A by-product of Alaqa's dark experiments.
Pieces of armor crafted by Forgemaster H'naanza, veteran armorer Blanstyr...and YOU!
Pronounced “cra-bopple,” unlike the crab apple, when ripened to a bright red, crabapples are amazingly sweet and delicious.
Though long removed from the head, you have the eerie feeling this eye is still watching you.
Property of one Drydox, this hempen bag is perilously overstuffed with all manner of oddly shaped rummage.
Young plump leaves plucked from a carnivorous narbrooi.
A rare type of tadpole prized by fishers for its tendency to thrash about the water, long after being impaled on a fishing hook.
Coin entrusted to you by the goblin Feltsmox to pay for fishing bait.
A highly complex instrument used to gauge the stability of an aetheryte.
The beautiful feather of a bird not often seen outside the Orn Wild.
A thick layer of fat surrounds what is otherwise extremely lean meat.
A wooden box filled with various odds and ends wrongfully taken from Midnight Dew of Idyllshire.
Several parchment bills notarized by the Clan Centurio stating the reward for the slaying of certain wanted monsters.
Several parchment bills notarized by the Clan Centurio stating the reward for the slaying of certain wanted monsters.
Several parchment bills notarized by the Clan Centurio stating the reward for the slaying of certain wanted monsters.
A parchment bill notarized by the Clan Centurio stating the reward for the slaying of a certain notorious and deadly monster.
An official-looking document, complete with a wax seal and the signature of Alchemists' Guild guildmaster Severian in what appears to be...blood (or perhaps simply red ink).
Strange glyphs and seemingly random markings clutter what appears to be a map of Silvertear Falls and the outlying areas.

Though labeled a crozier by the Sons of Saint Coinach who unearthed the relic, it is unlikely this crooked staff was used for religious purposes, as it is well documented that most late Third Astral Era Allagans abandoned the theological in order to pursue the technological.
A mundane account of daily occurrences in the life of a man now believed dead.
Alchemists' Guild guildmaster Severian claims this mixture of finely ground minerals and chitin can, when applied to a substance, discern the color of the aether contained within.
A family treasure of House Jervaint, this bejeweled sword has been passed down from father to son for countless generations. Numerous nicks and scratches suggest it has not been treated with care.
A beautifully carved rosary entrusted to you by the Lady Laurisse.
The use of cermet in its design makes this transportation crate resistant to heat and cold, and will protect its contents from a drop up to a thousand yalms (but not a yalm more).
A piece of magitek equipment designed to obstruct aether-based communication.
A spindle of wool spun by aspiring chirurgeon Averil of Ishgard's West Colonnade.
A leather pouch so full of gil it is nearly bursting at the seams.
A rambling ode written over a span of two ales by the bard Aubrenard.
An envelope addressed to Geva, guildmaster of the Leatherworkers' Guild in Gridania. “Elde” is printed in small letters in the lower-right corner on the reverse side.
Samples of several of FenYll's best-selling items.
Coin provided by Elde as aid to the fledgling Ishgardian Mercantile Guild.
This expertly crafted footwear is not for resale.
A dark stain situated at the lower end of the weathered rod suggests that it has been someone's tackle of choice for quite a long while.
Judging by its otherworldly smoothness, one might assume Ansaulme spent at least three to four moons polishing this fine pole.
Celebrated composer Pierryvain worked three days and nights without sleep to create these modern arrangements inspired by traditional choir chants.

Crafted by the ninja Oboro, these tiny spherical incendiaries do not contain any firesand, rather a pair of liquids separated by a thin oilskin wall. When thrown upon the ground, the two liquids mix, causing a reaction which produces a billowing cloud of noxious smoke.
If you had a sack of gil for every time someone entrusted you with a sack of gil, you would need a bigger sack.
The soothing aroma of this incense made from Althyk lavender is thought to ease the mind and heart, and in turn, induce sleep.
An envelope stuffed with identification papers drawn up by the Miners' Guild guildmaster Adalberta.
A large enough chunk as to be a guide for finding larger deposits.
Never before have you seen such luster in an ore, though in your short time in the realm, you have yet to see much of Eorzea's ore.
The only thing between you and the copious amount of gold coins, chalices, and candelabras in this weighty poke is a nigh on indecipherable knot.

Also known as ruby silver, this rare greyish red mineral is oft found near veins of regular silver. For every hundred ponzes of silver a miner excavates, however, she will be lucky to find even a ponze of fire silver.
Headgear common to the Sultansworn elite.
Arm gear common to the Sultansworn elite.
Foodstuffs, medicines, and tools intended for use in Falcon's Nest.
A simple pendant crafted from a thin leather strap and a single white highland falcon feather.
A farming instrument used in the Sixth Astral Era by residents of Falcon's Nest.
Enough wine was stored in this box to render a whole company of knights merry, or a single knight blind.
One whiff is all that is needed to realize something is slightly off-kilter with this bottle's contents.
One whiff is all that is needed to realize something is slightly off-kilter with this bottle's contents.
Details on the symptoms exhibited by several poisoned soldiers.
A red-hot piece of smoldering wood. It must be blown on periodically to ensure it doesn't flicker out.
Sigan has entrusted you with these herbs for reasons better documented in your journal than here.

Zu living in the far reaches of Eorzea are known to consume a highly toxic variety of brambleweed known as “thorny viper.” The plant's toxin collects in the cloudkin's blood, making zu meat almost as deadly as the zu itself.
The bite marks on this beastkin bone are arranged in a curious pattern that seems almost unnatural.
The bite marks on this beastkin bone are arranged in a curious pattern that seems almost unnatural.
A scale from a fallen tulihand, used to draw further servants of the Dravanian Horde into the field.
A scale from a fallen wadjet, used to draw further servants of the Dravanian Horde into the field.
The fang of a dragon slain by your own hand.
Judging from the numerous tears and bite marks, the previous owner of this chainmail did not make it out of the suit alive.
The fang of a dragon slain by your own hand.
The giant femur of a wyvern. How you expect this to fit into your traveler's bag is a mystery best left for another time.
The skinned tail of the amphibious clearwater nanka. The meat is exceptionally lean, and when fresh, can be eaten raw (though a dab of Mun-Tuy sauce is recommended to mask the bog-like aftertaste).
Cleaned and filleted, a single adult jagil can feed an entire extended family of Lalafells.
Taken from the foreleg of a loaghtan─an ancient breed of sheep once believed extinct─this particular cut of meat has a thin covering of fat which adds flavor when braised.
Though weathered and worn, letters carved upon this stone can still be made out beneath patches of lichen. It appears to be an accounting of dragons being granted succor by an Elezen healer.
A thin-leafed grass-like plant found growing in the Dravanian forelands.
An infusion made with actual wyvern tails would probably be kinder to the tongue than this foul concoction brewed from the Dravanian plant of the same name.
Though weathered and worn, letters carved upon this stone can still be made out beneath patches of lichen. It appears to be an accounting of dragon being granted succor by an Elezen healer.
Proof that you defeated a terrifying tsanahale. Unless, that is, you simply found this beak lying about in the grass.
Two thick leather straps woven into a bridle large enough to fit over the head of a sanuwa. Used by the Vanu Vanu when riding the massive snakelike creatures.

A timeworn archaeoskin map revealing the location of an unknown treasure.

※Level 55 recommended.

A timeworn wyvernskin map revealing the location of an unknown treasure.

※Level 60 recommended.

A timeworn dragonskin map revealing the location of an unknown treasure.

※Level 60 full party (8 players) recommended.

A mushroom found growing in Cloudtop. The Ishgardian knight who first discovered the queerly shaped fungus, and hence had the privilege of naming the new species, claims he had a slightly more clever name in mind, but forgot it.
Sanson's journal, filled cover to cover with writings on song.
A small piece of shattered aetheryte.
Completely free of vilekin larvae, spriggan feces, nanka eggs, and mind-altering funguar spores.
A goblin-crafted pickaxe available for rent from the fine bucolic folk at Idyllshire.
A stained leather log filled with peculiar shapes and symbols. Several blue fingerprints mark the cover.
An indecipherably complex and extensive system for lending tools to prospectors visiting Idyllshire.
A map of the Dravanian hinterlands with borders of land ownership redrawn by Dripwix.
An oily, rancid, suppurating slice of vilekin abdomen. Even the threat of starvation could not convince you of devouring this disgustful morsel.
A charred, fragrant, juicy slice of roasted heaven. Even the threat of eternal damnation could not convince you to keep your mouth off this ambrosial morsel.
The dried meat of water buffalo native to the Orn Wild. A goblin staple for long journeys.
This light-brown liquid has no odor or flavor, but goblins swear by its stomach-settling properties.
It would be in your best interest to deliver it to the addressee.
An envelope stuffed with several pieces of parchment and sealed with the giant “I” of Idyllshire.
Documents signed by Dripwix are contained within this nondescript envelope.
The flavorful seed of a kupo tree, the kupo nut is cherished by moogles across the realm.
The flavorful seed of a kupo tree, the kupo nut is cherished by moogles across the realm.
The flavorful seed of a kupo tree, the kupo nut is cherished by moogles across the realm.
A single sable pinion from an unknown creature. Judging from the size of the feather, the unknown creature is undeniably large.
A handwritten message from Morgayne requesting that Lydirlona share with you her knowledge of collectables.
A handwritten message from Lydirlona requesting that Alderan share with you his knowledge of specialists.
A handwritten message from Lydirlona requesting that Kokosamu share with you his knowledge of aetherial reduction.
A handwritten message from Lydirlona granting you permission to trade collectables with Geimlona in Idyllshire.
An ancient currency believed to have once been used in the foothills of Abalathia's Spine. In the center of each coin is a hole so tiny that it begs the question how it was opened.
The biting aroma of this white narrow mushroom cannot be described without using terms that would make a maiden blush.
Gysahl greens so aromatic, if you were a chocobo, you would have eaten them already.
Though rarely seen anymore, mention of the lilies is common in tomes from the early Sixth Astral Era, as well as children's faerie tales, suggesting the flowers once grew across Coerthas.

A hodgepodge mixture of seemingly random items from Wedge's workspace. The engineer claims it can be used to detect the presence of certain crystals within solid matter. He has also asked that you do not ask him again about why it is called 3G7-001B.
Unsure of its origin, Roundrox has given this light-emitting rock a compound name─a linguistic convention common in the goblin tongue.
Pages torn from what appears to be a Sharlayan tome on engineering techniques used in the crafting of an automated nose hair-clipping device.
It whizzles. It pops. All else is a mystery regarding this Illuminati-crafted contraption.
The message printed in bold black letters across the flyer's face reads, “A call to all independent freethinkers. Join us in building a paradise free from the hate and corruption plaguing Eorzea.”
A leather bag containing an item prepared by the Leatherworkers' Guild as per Tataru's request.
A cloth bag containing the item prepared by the Conjurers' Guild as per Tataru's request.
Remittance for a pot of sleep-inducing lavender incense, payable to the Qiqirn merchant Kyokyoroon.
Sour red cooked with various spices and citrus rinds over a low flame so as to preserve the alcoholic content.
A mixture of chopped fresh greens and hay for delivery to the Holy Stables.
Splintered, knotted, cracked, worm-eaten, moldering─this wood is no longer suitable for aught but maintaining a fire.
A sealed envelope containing an official invitation to a banquet hosted by House Fortemps.
An oil painting depicting the Fury helmed and astride a dragon.
If the sickly-sweet words of eternal love contained within this missive are not enough to induce nausea, the copious amounts of rose oil applied to the parchment most certainly will.
The sigil on this pennon is so battle worn that it is barely recognizable as that of House Haillenarte.
In times of darkness, when all hope has left the land, leaving its inhabitants mere husks of what they once were...what better than a hot bowl of soup to fill the void in their hearts?
A hempen bag containing the worldly possessions of now-deceased petty thief Osaulie.
The round gemstone heavily aspected to both water and wind is believed by the Zundu tribe to be one of the eyes of the Manukmanai, a great beast of Vanu legend.
The round gemstone heavily aspected to both earth and fire is believed by the Gnath to be an eye Ravana lost thousands of years ago at the hands of a rival tribe's hero.
One would have to sink her teeth into the scruff of a newborn billygoat to get meat fresher than this.
Thousands of gil worth of goods imported from exotic locales.
Several metal rings hinged together to spin and rotate independently of one another. What this fantastic creation could be used for is beyond you.
An unmarked hempen sack Joye has yet to deliver to Haillenarte Manor.
Complex-looking contraptions employed by the Garlean Empire to repair their magitek machinery.
The bearer of this seal is to be granted admission to the Holy See as an honored visitant of House Dzemael.

The aetherial balance of this crystal is tipped completely to the element lightning. Not a single trace of any of the other five elements can be detected. The Vanu Vanu keep crystals such as these under lock and key, bringing them forth only to use in tribal ceremonies.
A letter to the Holy See officially requesting the assembly of Ishgard's top astrologians to discuss matters of the utmost import.
A slip of parchment documenting plans for an airship test flight.
Bottomless only in the sense that it has a hole in the bottom...
This slab of cooled magma does not appear to contain any air bubbles, almost but ensuring that it will withstand the flames of a dragon when used in a rampart wall.
The number of air bubbles in this heavy black slab are cause for worry if the stone is to be used for deflecting the flames of a dragon.
Not too small, not too large, this roundish stone the size of a Lalafellin head is the perfect size for repairing the Anvil watchtower near Falcon's Nest.
The sharp, unweathered edges of this unevenly shaped rock suggest that it is recently broken off from a larger piece.
Stone smoothed by countless moons of exposure to wind and rain.
A heavy stone covered with swirling heretical patterns painted in what could or could not be blood.
A large rectangular slab of moss-covered rock used in the foundation of ruins located in the Chocobo Forest.
A rare type of metallic ore that resembles a cluster of needles or miniature lances.
An uncut, unpolished stone containing what appears to be a larger-than-normal sapphire.
A nondescript stone mined from one of the many floating islands in the Churning Mists. Now removed from the island, the rock no longer exhibits levitative properties.
A lump of nondescript soil retrieved from one of the many floating islands in the Churning Mists. Now removed from the island, the soil no longer exhibits levitative properties.

A fine, deep-blue sand found in relative abundance on the floating islands in the Churning Mists. The lack of similarly blue rocks on the islands has Eorzean scholars of geology at a loss as to where the sand may have originated.
Whoever used this arrowhead used it long, long ago.
Whoever exchanged this currency for goods and services, did it a long, long time ago.
Only a fool would mistake this bright-red ore for real furite.
This fine sand appears to be made up of tiny wind crystal shards, making it lighter than regular sea sand.
Despite being larger than an oliphant's ear, this piece of pumice weighs less than a chocobo down pillow.
A piece of pumice so light, you would not know it were in your hand unless you were looking at it.
This chunk of pommel ore is almost completely void of impurities.
There is no record of pommel ore until its discovery in the Dravanian hinterlands upon the Calamity-formed rock formations known as the Daggers.
A crystal so clear and free of impurities or air bubbles that it is nigh invisible.
A large, flat stone used to pave the streets and reinforce the walls of Sharlayan.
A large, flat stone used to pave the streets and reinforce the walls of Sharlayan. A large crack down the center makes it less than fit for reuse.
The thicker the roots, the more vital juices that can be extracted from the rubycress. This root will provide enough sap to reduce the swelling of strumae in at least seventeen babies.
The earthy flavored roots of this crimson-leafed herb are used to cure a variety of infant ailments, from colic to croup to chocopox.
A billowy plant employed in various Halonic ceremonies of blessing and purification.
Due to their natural resistance to colder temperatures, hemlocks remain abundant in Coerthas even now, long after the Calamity-induced winter killed off the less hardy species.
When seasoned, this thick sap-filled branch will prove quick-lighting and hot-burning, making it the perfect kindling.
This particular sample of gentian contains not a single withered or blighted leaf.
The dried leaves and blossoms of gentians are often made into teas which soothe upset stomachs.
For reasons only known to themselves, bitterdrake is avoided by most Dravanians like the plague, despite not being bitter at all.

A segment of the hard exposed root of a caelumtree. Scholars of botany are unclear as to why such a large portion of the caelumtree's roots grow above ground in a similar fashion to the mangroves of Mor Dhona, despite the lack of marsh-like conditions in the Dravanian forelands. Some, however, have concluded that the area must once have been submerged in water for an extended period of time─a time in which the trees adapted. And though the waters have receded, the roots remain the same.

Though similar in color to Trader vetch, similar in shape to quickweed, and similar in fragrance to an Azeyma rose, you lack sufficient knowledge in Eorzean flora to determine whether or not this species of Dravanian plant is any of the three.
You can safely say that, despite your lack of knowledge in Eorzean flora, there exists nothing like this plant in the lower realm.
An ancient variety of dandelion that has not been seen in lower Eorzea since the Fifth Astral Era.
An unidentifiable weed of some sort that appears to have had all its young leaves partially devoured by a beast with small, yet sharp teeth.
While not bearing any resemblance to lettuce, the moogles of the Churning Mists insist this is what the landlords who once resided on the area's floating islands called the leafy vegetable.
Several times larger than a maiden artichoke, it is difficult to imagine that this cyclopean specimen is in any manner as palatable as its lowland cousin.
This flower blooms in clusters, giving it the appearance of a fluffy blue cloud.
The soothing aroma of this nectar eases the mind and calms the soul.
The odor of this viscous nectar is sweet almost to the point of being sickly, bringing to mind overripe bananas or rotting pears.
A variety of cedar which contains a deep-brown sap that makes the wood appear almost black.
Due to its rich color, black cedar is often used as a substitute for the more expensive ebonwood.
A knob-shaped stolon emerging from the exposed root of a tree.
To put this young branch to the torch seems a mighty shame, so perfect would its thickness and flexibility be for whipping a naughty troublemaker into shape, but needs must.

This branch is far too hard to be of any use as a disciplinary measure, as it likely to snap in two after several floggings, but the acrid smoke it emits when burnt more than makes up for this unfortunate shortcoming.

An excerpt from the chapter entitled “Of Sallow Vizards,” the words and symbols written in blood upon these pages are said to bind terrible creatures. If disturbed, the ward will weaken, possibly allowing the creatures to escape.

An excerpt from the chapter entitled “His Treasure Forhelen,” the words and symbols written in blood upon these pages are said to bind terrible creatures. If disturbed, the ward will weaken, possibly allowing the creatures to escape.
When thrown on the ground, these tiny pellets release a noxious smoke that disorients anything in the immediate vicinity.
Dragons of the Horde will often treat each other's scales with flame to harden them, improving defense against spear thrust.
A lean strip of meat taken from right above the cloudkin's heart.
Fragrant fertilizer formed from decaying foliage and fermenting fecal matter.
The colorful feather of a baleful gastornis.
A Dravanian forelands flower whose dragonspeak name roughly translates into “calming tree.”
A common weed whose seeds rattle inside their pom-like pods when dried.
An orb of crystallized water aether that, when shattered, releases large amounts of fresh water─a scarce resource in the Sea of Clouds.
A letter of introduction written by Goldsmiths' Guild guildmaster Serendipity to House Haillenarte.
A letter found on the body of a Sharlayan thaumaturge. The cracked seal appears somewhat familiar.
Coin provided as aid to the fledgling Ishgardian Mercantile Guild.
A newly constructed exosphere designed to contain an Allagan system node.
A large round sapphire named after the icy blue sheen of the Fury's armor.
The rounded scale of a giant breed of sanuwa known as waukkeons. The Vanu Vanu have found their oval shape suited for the creation of tribal masks.
Studies show wild chocobo feathers harbor far more fleas than feathers taken from domesticated chocobos. A fact undisputed long before the study was even held.

A glass case containing a wind-aspected needle balanced on a pin. Nearby aether currents exert torque on the pin, “pulling” it in their direction.

This item has been moved to your collection.
A heavy iron key used to unlock certain doors in Pharos Sirius.
This surprisingly light key is coated in a sticky film whose origins are best not speculated upon.

Haddock so fresh its accusatory stare compels you to toss it back to the sea that it may live a long and fruitful life.

※Not included in the fish guide.
Carefully removed from the wreckage of a mysterious “bug,” this fragment appears to be made of metal, albeit one you cannot recognize.
The wandering engineer's ruminations on the bug scrap you retrieved.
Brewed in the bilge of a leaky galleon, this foul potable removes paint about as well as it warms bellies.
A sweet cookie given to good boys and ghouls during All Saints' Wake.
A simple wooden broom bearing the taint of witchery.
All that remains of a burned witch's broom.
A surprisingly accurate depiction of the missing Thancred, suggesting that Alphinaud may have mistaken his life's calling.
A rusted knife similar to those most commonly carried by sailors to cut rope. The tool is featureless save for the name “Diamanda” crudely carved into its haft.

Across the face of this massive femur salvaged from the corpse of an unidentifiable creature has been carved an intricate whorling pattern that represents the everlasting bonds of friendship between Linu Vali and Ginu Vanu.

When blown, these horns will emit a piercing tone that resembles the cry of a sanuwa fledgling, effectively summoning an adult trained for riding. This particular specimen appears to have been in disuse for quite some time.
Free of most impurities, this beautiful pink salt harvested from Abalathia's Spine is almost entirely transparent.
Named for the shape of its flowers, this common herb is found on most of the Sea of Clouds' floating islets. It is also often referred to as “isle grass” to the less metaphorically inclined.
A soft, sticky confection made with ground catsfoot leaves to give it a bright emerald green color.
You suspect very little tinder will be required to ignite these well-seasoned logs.
A queerly shaped vase used by the Vundu tribe to not only store, but also ferment their food.
A crystal so aspected to water that it feels wet to the touch.
A plump and juicy slice of wamouracampa flesh. When cooked over a fire, its flavor is best likened to grilled crawler.
Carved from bone, these fine-toothed combs are used by both males and females of the Zundu tribe to groom their feathers.
Moist nutrient-rich soil perfect for growing crops, raising worms, or burying treasure.
Thinly sliced abdomen flesh removed of prolegs and bristles and ready to eat.
Several bells of slow cooking is recommended to soften this tough cloudkin flesh.
Ishgardian steel is slow to rust, making it optimal for use in items that are in constant exposure to the elements.
A heavy rock-like growth removed from the body of a Sea of Clouds-dwelling golem.
Depending on the size of the animal, the thighbone of a dhalmel can grow up to seven fulms in length and weigh as much as twenty-five ponzes.
A crude ceramic pot containing dyes used by the Vundu tribe to color feathers and clothing, even tattoo beaks.
Within this massive silk capsule can be heard the stirring of a wamoura on the verge of eclosure.
Prolonged exposure to attractant found in a variety of local flora is most likely the cause for this young gaelicat being separated from its clowder.
Rotundity being a barometer for beauty in the queer creatures, this particular specimen would most certainly rank high amongst korrigan enthusiasts.
Not as downy as actual down, but hands down the downright downiest feather you will ever bring down.
A soft, sticky confection filled with ground catsfoot leaves to give it a bright emerald green color. Just like grandmother used to make.
Proposals as to why this particular paissa practically percolates with perkiness are pending.
Balmy to the touch, this wind crystal's aspect leans ever so slightly to fire.

Several days after blooming, the flower of the weeping wildwort will turn away from the sun and down to the ground, making it appear that it is “hanging its head,” and thus earning the plant its name.
A slightly luminous stone of unknown origin. It may have some connection with Iroha's lost memories.
A slightly luminous stone of unknown origin. It may have some connection with Iroha's lost memories.
A slightly luminous stone of unknown origin. It may have some connection with Iroha's lost memories.
The size of this egg suggests that the fledgling incubating within will eventually grow to a remarkable size...unless it is made into an omelette first.
An iron bell used to signal the time of day. It is accompanied by a piece of sheet music.
An iron bell once used to signal the time of day, repurposed for use in the Starlight Celebration. It is accompanied by a piece of sheet music.
Cloudcrawler is a swift-growing vine that clings to the bottoms of islets found in the Sea of Clouds. When dried, the vines are pliable enough to weave into baskets or even crude armor.
A simple sack woven in a similar manner by nearly all of the Vanu Vanu tribes living in the Sea of Clouds.

Also known as “arare mochi,” this sticky Far Eastern canapé has, in recent years, evolved into a Little Ladies' Day staple. Why a decidedly Far Eastern dish has become the symbol of a decidedly Ul'dahn holiday is a question that has stumped local anthropologists for weeks. This particular cake comes packaged in a piece of parchment promoting a performance by popular prepubescent trio, the Songbirds.
Though shorter than the femur, the shank bone of an adult dhalmel can still measure up to six fulms in length.
Upon this card is written your name, nameday, and other vital information the stars refuse to reveal to fortune-tellers.
A Valentione's card misplaced by Hortefense.
Freshly pounded glutinous rice, coated with fine-ground starch and rolled into a ball. A Heavensturn tradition in the Far East.
This dried grass has been treated with a small amount of water so that it will emit copious amounts of smoke when lit.
An undying flame retrieved from the realm of Ifrit.
An untamed wind retrieved from the realm of Garuda.
An unbreakable stone retrieved from the realm of Titan.
Correspondence from Lucia, addressed to Hilda.
An important section broken from Roundrox's prized treasure and entrusted to none other than you.
Containing a variety of ground herbs and natural oils, the recipe for this traditional medicine has been passed down for generations.
A gadget attached to a colorful wristband. While it appears to be some sort of clockwork mechanism, it shows no sign of movement.
A long green branch cut from a young melia. When fashioned into an arrow shaft, it is less likely to split when loosed.
This wood has been dried and chopped, and is ready to toss on a fire.
A long green branch cut from a young melia. When fashioned into an arrow shaft, it is less likely to split when loosed.
This perennial plant was introduced to Eorzea by the Sharlayans. Growing unchecked after the exodus, it has since spread and become an indigenous plant of the Dravanian forelands.
Fogweed, cured with fire shards and finely chopped. Residents of Tailfeather claim the fragrant aroma helps calm their nerves while on the hunt.
A handcrafted jar filled to the brim with a viscous paste.
This soft, moist, yet foul-smelling blackloam is said to be part of a strict dietary regimen for Onemind soldiers.
This red-tinged sand occurs in abundance in and around Avalonia Fallen.
Hardwood branches that have been left exposed to the sun and are now perfect for producing lump charcoal.
A fragrant herb with silver leaves that, when rubbed, turn a bright green.
Though slightly soiled, once dusted off, this deliciously ripe fruit will make for a splendid ingredient.

A wine that utilizes several rather unique ingredients, including the sweet juices of the caelumtree fruit. The resulting alcoholic beverage ensnares the senses with its full-bodied flavor and delightful aroma.
Low-grade cut of chocobo meat with little to no market value.
Scratchy fur obtained from a bandersnatch, which if properly tanned will be able to fend off even the most frigid of winds.
A succulent shrimp found in the Hundred Throes, aptly named for its resemblance to Gnath claws.
Scores of tiny black eggs suspended in a sac of foul-smelling slime. Adult nankas carry these sacs on their backs until incubation is complete.
A sweet-smelling herb that grows along the Whilom River in the Dravanian forelands.
A fragrant herb native to the Dravanian forelands. It is often found growing along the Danneroad near Anyx Trine.
A peculiar assortment of ten Dravanian herbs that smell pleasant on their own, but may have unwanted results when blended together.
A neatly wrapped parcel with the name Uhm Ala written across it in dark, spiraling letters.

Though it appears to be naught more than a simple stone, Garlond Ironworks engineers insist it contains reams of invaluable information gathered by the lost Allagan Empire on the subject of the Fiend, Sephirot.
A small sylphic satchel filled with a soft, silvery substance.
Unlike a natural eggshell, it is rough to the touch and leaves a dusty, white residue on the fingers.
A plain white egg that has been gilded and decorated by a Dreamer.
A fine mesh woven from supple fibers that is able to withstand even the hottest of temperatures.
A low-burning Bombard that has been bound with a flame-resistant net.
A blood-encrusted ring found affixed to a pair of rusted gauntlets.

A tome which contains detailed descriptions about various Yo-kai.

This item has been moved to your collection.

A faded map revealing the location of a teleportation portal leading to an ancient ruin filled with untold riches.

※Level 60 full party (8 players) recommended.
※Average item level 180 recommended.
A crate of supplies sent by the Temple Knights, intended for delivery to Bahrr Lehs.
A letter addressed to Handeloup and signed in Tarresson's elegant hand.
A statuette depicting Shiva and Hraesvelgr, seized by the Temple Knights.
A stone fragment found amongst the rubble of Bahrr Lehs. The worn lettering may have once formed a message, but it is impossible to tell with this fragment alone.
A set of tools and training materials, which have been packaged and are to be distributed to new recruits.
Loose timber salvaged from the Landlord Colony, a handful of which appears to be slightly charred around the edges.
Hunks of rusted metal that have begun to crumble and flake with age.
A budding plant with long, fibrous roots. After being dried for a period in the sun and then briefly dipped in water, the plant becomes pliable enough to twirl into the most elaborate of baskets.
A seemingly useless piece of wood recovered from the ruins of the Landlord Colony.
A set of three similarly sized and shaped stone blocks, burnished to a glossy finish.
The passage of time has turned this birch log to stone.
A generous helping of grilled mushrooms and other local vegetables, spiced and drowned in a thick broth.
A crystal of superb quality harvested from a Churning Mists kupa tree.
An ancient instrument of unique design, the sound of which is said to call a mechanical dragon down from the skies...assuming the legends are true.
A list of miscellaneous supplies required for Ulan's research.
A unique looking glass crafted by Arnott to determine the aetherial composition of arcane entities.
Stiff, bristly plates from a molting adolescent wyvern.
A cloudfish that appears to be missing from the existing list of documented fauna in the Churning Mists.
Ninety-nine birds' nests, crushed into a cube and tied with string.
A worn pouch overflowing with wadjet spines.
A ragged-looking box filled to the top with wind-aspected crystals.
A bowl of traditional stew, accompanied by a moogle-sized spoon and refreshing beverage to wash everything down.
An iron key that can be used to open a door...but which one?
A seasonal treat prepared for visitors to the haunted manor.
A live coal used to light lanterns.
When thrown at a transformed skinchanger, this bomb is said to emit a distinctive blue smoke.
A curious bead believed by the Ixal to contain the life essence of Garuda herself.
A curious bead believed by the Ixal to contain the life essence of Garuda herself.
A bleached white key carved from what could be the bone of an Ixal...or that of a domestic chicken.
Though it appears to be naught more than a simple stone, Unukalhai insists it contains reams of invaluable information gathered by the lost Allagan Empire on the subject of the Goddess, Sophia.
A quick glance at the pages of this hefty volume reveals what appear to be the titles of manifold books and manuscripts, each accompanied by an arcane string of symbols and numerals.
Entrusted to you by its elderly owner that he may receive a vigorous massage, this suit of armor is surprisingly light and reeks of garlic.
A large quantity of crystals intended for Titan's summoning.

The old grey mare, she ain't what she used to be,♪
Ain't what she used to be, ain't what she used to be...♪
The contents of this festively wrapped parcel are sure to warm the hearts of the children.
A letter addressed to Reauverre that you found hidden beneath the boy's bed.
A gift that was waiting for you under a Starlight Tree upon waking from a most remarkable dream.
A gift for young Reauverre that his father hopes will raise the boy's spirits.
The first of three gripping tales chronicling the Warrior of Light's adventures in Eorzea.
A small wooden crate emblazoned with the seal of Frondale's Phrontistery.
A seemingly normal piece of cloth, woven with magic by Angelet.
Though you cannot discern the change in this magicked cloth, its presence makes you feel uneasy.
A bottle of ceruleum, carefully distilled to remove all impurities.

A journal to record stories of bravery and derring-do, lovingly crafted and illustrated by Khloe Aliapoh. Fill it with tales of your adventures and return it to the imaginative Miqo'te child, and she just may have a special gift for you!
The second of three gripping tales chronicling the Warrior of Light's adventures in Eorzea.
The final installment in a series of tales chronicling the Warrior of Light's adventures in Eorzea.
Distilled by Blamprest using a recipe of his own creation, some claim the full extent of its inebriating effects can only be enjoyed in the light of the moon.
Judging from the wear and tear of the parchment, this elegantly penned document entrusted to you by Y'shtola appears to be quite ancient.
A remnant of an Allagan killing machine.
Originally designed by Arnott, this looking glass has been modified to determine the aetheric density of arcane entities.
A rare gemstone plucked from the Crystallum in the heart of the Lost City of Amdapor.
A curious Sharlayan poppet found in the Rare Tomes Room in the Great Gubal Library.
Molten rock from the belly of Sohm Al, said to be possessed of preternatural power.
Though it appears to be naught more than a simple stone, Unukalhai insists it contains reams of invaluable information gathered by the lost Allagan Empire on the subject of the Demon, Zurvan.
It rubs the oil on his skin. It does this whenever it is told.
The aetheric energy emitted by this lightning crystal fragment appears to have adverse effects on the surrounding environment.
The aetheric energy emitted by this fire crystal fragment appears to have adverse effects on the surrounding environment.
The aetheric energy emitted by this earth crystal fragment appears to have adverse effects on the surrounding environment.
The aetheric energy emitted by this ice crystal fragment appears to have adverse effects on the surrounding environment.

The aetheric energy emitted by this wind crystal fragment appears to have adverse effects on the surrounding environment.
A crystalline manifestation of aetheric lightning energy exhibiting an extreme elemental charge.
A crystalline manifestation of aetheric fire energy exhibiting an extreme elemental charge.
A crystalline manifestation of aetheric earth energy exhibiting an extreme elemental charge.
A crystalline manifestation of aetheric ice energy exhibiting an extreme elemental charge.

A crystalline manifestation of aetheric wind energy exhibiting an extreme elemental charge.
The best of the best for a Manderville man,♪To rise to the top as the cream only can,♪So for the lack of a logical plan,♪Massage the Mander-Manderville man!♪
A cylindrical identification key. Used to operate a specific magitek security terminal.
A cylindrical identification key. Used to operate a specific magitek security terminal.
A cylindrical identification key. Used to operate a specific magitek security terminal.
A cylindrical identification key. Used to operate a specific magitek security terminal.
A mysterious whistle that, when sounded by a worthy soul, is said to call forth a fiery bird of Far Eastern legend.
A potent concoction of herbs used to alleviate the symptoms of severe heart conditions.
A decorative egg awarded for delivering a jolly good shock.
A decorative egg awarded for delivering a jolly good shock.
A Manderville Gold Saucer VIP card personally stamped with the House Manderville signet by Godbert himself.
Papers that prove your Miners' Guild status personally written by Adalberta herself.
Research materials gathered by Rowena at Nonowato's request.
Pollen collected from a Diadem cloudtrap. It exudes a sharp but oddly enticing aroma.
The liver of a flood worm. Though unappetizing in appearance, its musky scent is strangely pleasing to inhale.
This experimental elixir is said to have an enervating effect on select species found in the Diadem.
A specimen of bone harvested from a creature native to the Diadem.
An organ harvested from a creature native to the Diadem.
A katana of self-defense forged by a strong-willed Far Eastern girl you encountered at the Lominsan ferry docks.
A set of new tools forged for Sekka by you and Forgemaster Brithael. It consists primarily of a custom-made hammer and several secondary blacksmith tools.
An assortment of yellow wildflowers, perfect for any number of joyful or somber occasions. Handpicked by you.
Simple, practical, and nondescript, this trademark tool of the shinobi comes with a near-unlimited supply of sleeping darts.
The contents of this pouch are a mystery, but you may be assured of their efficacy in befuddling the mind and memories of hapless imperial soldiers.
A brittle lump of iron bestowed upon you by your client, Shinto, with which you are expected to forge a katana.
He misses his mother.
She's only a few years away from retirement.
An orchestrion's beating heart, where the music is made.
A package containing an elegant and compact orchestrion custom-made as a tribute for the sultana.
Page after page of the log is filled with a flowing script. Doubtless Beves has had much practice honing his handwriting.
Precisely what type of herb this is remains unclear, but the important thing is that it is green and fragrant.
A Resistance fighter's bloodstained bandana.
A hefty sack bursting with Thavnairian limestone.
A colorless, licorice-flavored drink considered a specialty of the Gyr Abanian region.
An orchestrion's outer case, crafted from fine lumber.
An orchestrion's ornamental trimmings, inlaid with beautiful gemstones.
Contaminated soil taken from the crash site of a Garlean craft in East End.
Murky water taken from the Velodyna River for testing.
The lean meat of the sarcosuchus is said to have the texture of chicken but with a faint fishy taste.
A curious mushroom found in the forests of East End. Their earthy, savory flavor greatly enhances any dish they're used in.
There is not a crack in the realm that cannot be mended with a paste made from one of these cores.
Small jars filled to the brim with oil used to coat cannons and prevent them from rusting.
A smooth white stone that is just slightly warm to the touch.
A bottle of arak bartered from the M tribe that has lost all of its bubbles.
Created by mashing a large number of dead ants together. Somewhat sticky to the touch.
A liquid secreted by large antlions. Often used for making disinfectants.
The putrid smell of this fish should draw any nearby sharks out of hiding.
Perhaps one day we will live in a world in which poor unkiu need not be slaughtered for Kojin rituals, but today is not that day.
At least, you think it's the YasakaninoMagatama. Not that you know for certain what it would look like.
Sacred treasure of the Kojin, this jewel is highly coveted by beastmen and kami alike.
An adorable cub of the exotic red panda species.
Crystalline-glazed stoneware used to store scorching-hot materials such as liquid magma.
A surprisingly accurate depiction of Yugiri and Gosetsu, once again suggesting that Alphinaud may have mistaken his life's calling.
Precious coral growing on the rocky seabottom noted for its crimson red hue.
A sword that was likely once worn at the hip of a samurai. The blade is tinged with slight traces of blood, but it is otherwise unremarkable in appearance.
A sea weed that is a brilliant red color, commonly found growing upon the rocky terrain of the Isle of Zekki.
Tiny bulbous mushrooms rumored to give you strength, or mayhap just the illusion of strength, when you most need it.
Stringy meat obtained from a malnourished island gedan.
They say all that glitters is not gold. 'Tis especially true for this miscellany of trinkets gathered by wildfowl to make their nests.
A carefully wrapped bundle of sun-dried fruits to offer in exchange for some artisanal bells.
A collection of incomplete bells that do not ring.
A tiny pebble used in Namazu neck bells.
A small wooden charm Meffrid clenched in his fist as he breathed his last.
An assortment of potions and potables that may prove invaluable in keeping the wounded alive on the journey back to Castrum Oriens.
A key ingredient in Chambui's buuz.
A viscous oil used to keep the lamps scattered throughout the Azim Steppe burning bright.
Several parchment bills notarized by the Clan Centurio stating the reward for the slaying of certain wanted monsters.
Several parchment bills notarized by the Clan Centurio stating the reward for the slaying of certain wanted monsters.
Several parchment bills notarized by the Clan Centurio stating the reward for the slaying of certain wanted monsters.
A parchment bill notarized by the Clan Centurio stating the reward for the slaying of a certain notorious and deadly monster.
An undecorated blade the Mol made at the behest of their gods.
What lies within this package is a mystery, but it gives off a pleasant smell.
A clear liquid with divine properties.
Wood to be cut into small, rectangular planks upon which will be inscribed prayers to Rhalgr, the Destroyer.

Wood to be cut into small, rectangular planks upon which will be inscribed prayers to Rhalgr, the Destroyer. The fine grain of this particular sample will serve to increase the planks' resistance to the elements.
The clear, viscous lifeblood of heavenspillars is collected by alchemists to concoct various ointments and unguents that are widely used to prevent the festering of wounds.
Bark that has long since peeled away from the trunk, shrinking and twisting as it dried.
Supple, green bark that had to be forcefully pulled to remove it from the tree's trunk.
A rough-cut log of Othardian pine timber.
A rough-cut log of Othardian pine timber, harvested from a tree estimated to be over a century old.
A piece of brilliant fan coral large enough to impress your friends, but small enough to fit in your pocket.
A strange, “plumed” sea creature that seemed far more elegant when it was swaying in the underwater currents than it does wedged in the bottom of your pack.
A hard, unbending stalk of yellow-brown bamboo.
A firm, yet pliant stalk of light-green bamboo.
A rough-cut log of Yanxian pine timber─a stout variety of pine that yields uncharacteristically hard wood treasured by furniture makers.
This swift-growing grass produces large bell-shaped seedpods which rattle in the autumn wind, earning it its name.
A single long stalk has emerged from the center of this particular sample of bellbloom, signifying that it will soon produce flowers.
